newsArray.content: Saudi Arabia announced on Wednesday it plans to bid to host the 2034 World Cup, the latest step in a campaign to turn the kingdom into a global sports powerhouse. The bid â€œintends to deliver a world-class tournament and will draw inspiration from Saudi Arabiaâ€™s ongoing social and economic transformation and the countryâ€™s deep-rooted passion for footballâ€, said a statement from the Saudi Arabian football federation. News of the bid comes one year after neighbouring Qatar hosted the first World Cup in the Middle East, where the Saudi national team scored a stunning group stage victory over eventual winners Argentina. The Saudi announcement came an hour after world footballâ€™s governing body FIFA released a statement giving its plans for the 2030 World Cup and inviting countries in the Asian Football Confederation to bid for 2034. On the heels of the Qatar tournament, Saudi Arabia signed Cristiano Ronaldo to play in the Saudi Pro League, the first in a slew of major stars drawn by eye-watering salaries to the worldâ€™s biggest crude oil exporter. Sport is a major component of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salmanâ€™s Vision 2030 reform agenda, which aims to transform Saudi Arabia into a tourism and business hub while transitioning the economy away from fossil fuels. â€“ Spending spree â€“ In the coming weeks, the kingdom is set to host the final LIV Golf League tournament of the regular season, a boxing match featuring Anthony Joshua and the Next Gen ATP Finals tennis tournament. It will also host the FIFA Club World Cup in December. Earlier this year, Saudi Arabia was confirmed as host of footballâ€™s 2027 Asian Cup. That event will enable Saudi officials to improve on existing football infrastructure, with new â€œworld-class stadiumsâ€ constructed â€œin the most sustainable waysâ€, Saudi Football Federation President, Yasser Al Misehal, said on Wednesday. Saudi Arabia previously explored a tri-continental World Cup bid with Egypt and Greece, though that plan has been shelved. The new Saudi-only bid means fans would face â€œmaximum three-hour flying times between cities and stadiumsâ€, Misehal said. In an interview with Fox News last month, Prince Mohammed dismissed those attacks, saying â€œI will continue doing sportswashingâ€ if it will benefit the Saudi economy. â€“ Prince in spotlight â€“ Hosting the World Cup would ratchet up scrutiny of the 38-year-old de facto ruler, who critics accuse of consolidating power through a fierce crackdown on dissent, including one recent case in which a retired teacher was sentenced to death for critical social media posts. Prince Mohammed told Fox he was â€œashamedâ€ of that verdict. World Cup-related construction could also draw a backlash from environmental activists who sounded the alarm last year after Saudi Arabia was awarded hosting rights for the 2029 Asian Winter Games, a 47-event competition to be held in Trojena, an area of the planned $500 billion futuristic megacity known as NEOM. At the time, Greenpeace questioned how plans for Trojena â€“ including a man-made freshwater lake, chalets, mansions and ultra-luxury hotels â€“ could possibly be sustainable. But Riyadh would be keen to use the World Cup as a showcase for various natural attractions, dispelling the notion that Saudi Arabia is one giant desert. But Misehal said on Wednesday that fans would be drawn to â€œour mountains, our islands and of course our cultureâ€, adding: â€œEverything will be connected with state-of-the-art facilities to guarantee an amazing fan experience.â€ The Asian Football Confederation came out in support of the Saudi 2034 World Cup bid shortly after it was announced on Wednesday. â€œI am delighted to note that the (Saudi football federation) have presented their intention to bid for the FIFA World Cup in 2034,â€ said AFC President Sheikh Salman bin Ibrahim Al Khalifa. â€œThe entire Asian football family will stand united in support of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabiaâ€™s momentous initiative, and we are committed to working closely with the global football family to ensure its success.â€ AFP

newsArray.title: 2030 World Cup to be hosted in three continents for first time
creator: TNM NewsDesk
newsArray.description: The News Mill
newsArray.content: The International Federation of Association Football (FIFA) on Tuesday announced a unique set-up for the World Cup 2030 which is set to be played on three different continents. Morocco, Portugal and Spain have been chosen as the sole candidate to host the World Cup. However in order to celebrate one of the biggest tournamentâ€™s 100th anniversary, centenary celebration and celebratory games will take place in Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. The first of these three matches which will be played in South America will be played at the stadium where it all began, in Montevideoâ€™s Estadio Centenario. With this, all six nations â€“ Morocco, Portugal, Spain, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay have directly qualified for the tournament. â€œThe FIFA Council unanimously agreed that the sole candidacy will be the combined bid of Morocco, Portugal, and Spain, which will host the event in 2030 and qualify automatically from the existing slot allocation subject to the completion of a successful bidding process conducted by FIFA and a decision by the FIFA Congress in 2024,â€ as quoted from a statement by FIFA. FIFA President Gianni Infantino talked about how football will be uniting different pasts of the world and said as quoted from the official website of FIFA, â€œIn a divided world, FIFA and football are uniting. The FIFA Council, representing the entire world of football, unanimously agreed to celebrate the centenary of the FIFA World Cup, whose first edition was played in Uruguay in 1930, in the most appropriate way. As a result, a celebration will take place in South America and three South American countries â€“ Uruguay, Argentina and Paraguay â€“ will organise one match each of the FIFA World Cup 2030. The first of these three matches will of course be played at the stadium where it all began, in Montevideoâ€™s mythical Estadio Centenario, precisely to celebrate the centenary edition of the FIFA World Cup.â€ â€œIn 2030, we will have a unique global footprint, three continents â€” Africa, Europe and South America â€” six countries â€” Argentina, Morocco, Paraguay, Portugal, Spain and Uruguay â€” welcoming and uniting the world while celebrating together the beautiful game, the centenary and the FIFA World Cup,â€ Infantino added.

newsArray.title: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp admits his call for Tottenham replay is unlikely
newsArray.description: With the score at 0-0, Liverpool forward Luis Diaz was flagged offside but replays showed he was actually onside, which VAR failed to correct.
newsArray.content: With the score at 0-0, Diaz was flagged offside but replays showed he was actually onside although Darren England, the VAR, mistakenly believed the on-field decision had been to award the goal, leading him to tell referee Simon Hooper the check was complete. Liverpoolâ€™s complaints promoted the publication of the audio between officials which revealed the first person to spot the mistake was the replay operator, who urged the team of officials to stop the game, but the VAR and assistant VAR repeatedly said they could not intervene because play had restarted. Klopp felt such an unprecedented scenario required a similarly unprecedented solution. â€œThe audio didnâ€™t change it at all because I was not really interested in why things happened because I knew,â€ he said. â€œI saw the outcome, I saw goal we scored and it didnâ€™t count so I wasnâ€™t now waiting for the audio and sitting there hoping Iâ€™d find out how it could happen or whatever. â€œYes, it was an obvious mistake and I think there would have been solutions for it afterwards. â€œIf not, I can say immediately â€“ and probably some people donâ€™t want me to say it â€“ not as the manager of Liverpool but, much more as a football person, I think the only outcome should be a replay. It probably will not happen. â€œThe argument against that will probably be if you open that gate then everybody will ask for it. I think the situation is that unprecedented â€“ it didnâ€™t happen before. â€œIâ€™m 56 years old and Iâ€™m absolutely used to wrong decisions, difficult decisions but something like that as far as I can remember has never happened. Thatâ€™s why I think the replay would be the right thing. â€œThe next argument would be if it would happen again, I think a replay would be the right thing to do or the referee has the opportunity to bring both coaches together and say â€˜sorry, we made a mistake, but we can sort it, that Liverpool score a goal and we start from thereâ€™.â€ PGMOL can confirm that we have carried out a review into the circumstances which led to the Luis Diaz goal being incorrectly disallowed for offside in the Premier League match between Tottenham Hotspur FC and Liverpool FC. Full statement and the audio between the on-field teamâ€¦ â€” PGMOL (@FA_PGMOL) Asked whether the club had made â€“ or would make â€“ a formal request for the match to be replayed Klopp, after taking advice from his press officer, said: â€œWe are still going through the information that we have.â€ The PA news agency understands the Premier Leagueâ€™s stance remains the same as earlier in the week â€“ that a replay would not be considered. The manager stressed he did not want to single out the individuals involved for the errors made, but wanted to find a solution within the framework of the system which would prevent something similar recurring in futrure. â€œWhat I want to say is itâ€™s really important that as big as football is, and important as it is for us, that we really deal with it in a proper way,â€ he added. â€œI mean that all the people involved â€“ on-field ref, linesman, fourth official and especially now in this case VAR â€“ they didnâ€™t do that on purpose. We shouldnâ€™t forget that. â€œIâ€™m not angry with any of them (the officials), not at all. Itâ€™s not only the respect, but the only thing for human beings in general is we should not go for them. Itâ€™s not allowed to go for them in any way. â€œThey made a mistake and they felt horrible that night, Iâ€™m 100 per cent sure. Thatâ€™s enough for me. Nobody needs further punishment. We should discuss it on a completely normal basis without emotions.â€ Klopp was still unhappy with some other decisions taken in the game, notably the upgrading of Curtis Jonesâ€™ yellow card to a red, and also the two yellow cards issued to Diogo Jota. â€œThe referee got called to the screen and saw for the first three seconds a frozen picture. I would have given immediately a red card for that picture. Then he sees the replay in slow motion and Iâ€™d have given a red card for the slow motion. But in reality itâ€™s not a red card. â€œThe refâ€™s first decision is yellow. Then the clear and obvious mistake is showing a frozen picture and in slow motion. â€œOn top of that, Diogo Jota got two yellow cards for not touching a player once. That is unprecedented as well I would say.â€ Jota will be available for Thursdayâ€™s Europa League visit of Belgian side Union Saint Gilloise but fellow forward Cody Gakpo, who was injured in the Spurs game, is out. At our arrival at Anfield ahead of tonight's training session, we paid tribute to the 97 victims of the Hillsborough disaster. â€” Royale Union Saint-Gilloise (@UnionStGilloise) Union coach Alexander Blessin believes he could have been a Klopp player himself for Mainz. â€œHe was planning his new squad. He called me and asked â€˜How are you?â€™ â€˜Fineâ€™, â€˜Blah blah blahâ€™ and we knew each other there a little bit,â€ said the German. â€œHe said weâ€™d stay in contact and I never heard anything back.â€ On his sideâ€™s chances he added: â€œWe need a really perfect day and they need a bad day. â€œWe will do everything and arenâ€™t here just drinking coffee saying â€˜Oh, itâ€™s niceâ€™.â€

News of the bid comes one year after neighbouring Qatar hosted the first World Cup in the Middle East, where the Saudi national team scored a stunning group stage victory over eventual winners Argentina. The Saudi announcement came an hour after world footballâ€™s governing body FIFA released a statement giving its plans for the 2030 World Cup and inviting countries in the Asian Football Confederation to bid for 2034. On the heels of the Qatar tournament, Saudi Arabia signed Cristiano Ronaldo to play in the Saudi Pro League, the first in a slew of major stars drawn by eye-watering salaries to the worldâ€™s biggest crude oil exporter. Sport is a major component of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salmanâ€™s Vision 2030 reform agenda, which aims to transform Saudi Arabia into a tourism and business hub while transitioning the economy away from fossil fuels. â€“ Spending spree â€“ In the coming weeks, the kingdom is set to host the final LIV Golf League tournament of the regular season, a boxing match featuring Anthony Joshua and the Next Gen ATP Finals tennis tournament. As a result, a celebration will take place in South America and three South American countries â€“ Uruguay, Argentina and Paraguay â€“ will organise one match each of the FIFA World Cup 2030. I think the situation is that unprecedented â€“ it didnâ€™t happen before. â€œIâ€™m 56 years old and Iâ€™m absolutely used to wrong decisions, difficult decisions but something like that as far as I can remember has never happened. Thatâ€™s why I think the replay would be the right thing. â€œThe next argument would be if it would happen again, I think a replay would be the right thing to do or the referee has the opportunity to bring both coaches together and say â€˜sorry, we made a mistake, but we can sort it, that Liverpool score a goal and we start from thereâ€™.â€ PGMOL can confirm that we have carried out a review into the circumstances which led to the Luis Diaz goal being incorrectly disallowed for offside in the Premier League match between Tottenham Hotspur FC and Liverpool FC. newsArray.content: The International Federation of Association Football (FIFA) on Tuesday announced a unique set-up for the World Cup 2030 which is set to be played on three different continents. Morocco, Portugal and Spain have been chosen as the sole candidate to host the World Cup. However in order to celebrate one of the biggest tournamentâ€™s 100th anniversary, centenary celebration and celebratory games will take place in Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. The first of these three matches which will be played in South America will be played at the stadium where it all began, in Montevideoâ€™s Estadio Centenario. With this, all six nations â€“ Morocco, Portugal, Spain, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay have directly qualified for the tournament. â€œThe FIFA Council unanimously agreed that the sole candidacy will be the combined bid of Morocco, Portugal, and Spain, which will host the event in 2030 and qualify automatically from the existing slot allocation subject to the completion of a successful bidding process conducted by FIFA and a decision by the FIFA Congress in 2024,â€ as quoted from a statement by FIFA. FIFA President Gianni Infantino talked about how football will be uniting different pasts of the world and said as quoted from the official website of FIFA, â€œIn a divided world, FIFA and football are uniting. The FIFA Council, representing the entire world of football, unanimously agreed to celebrate the centenary of the FIFA World Cup, whose first edition was played in Uruguay in 1930, in the most appropriate way. As a result, a celebration will take place in South America and three South American countries â€“ Uruguay, Argentina and Paraguay â€“ will organise one match each of the FIFA World Cup 2030. The first of these three matches will of course be played at the stadium where it all began, in Montevideoâ€™s mythical Estadio Centenario, precisely to celebrate the centenary edition of the FIFA World Cup.â€ â€œIn 2030, we will have a unique global footprint, three continents â€” Africa, Europe and South America â€” six countries â€” Argentina, Morocco, Paraguay, Portugal, Spain and Uruguay â€” welcoming and uniting the world while celebrating together the beautiful game, the centenary and the FIFA World Cup,â€ Infantino added.

newsArray.description: With the score at 0-0, Liverpool forward Luis Diaz was flagged offside but replays showed he was actually onside, which VAR failed to correct.
newsArray.content: With the score at 0-0, Diaz was flagged offside but replays showed he was actually onside although Darren England, the VAR, mistakenly believed the on-field decision had been to award the goal, leading him to tell referee Simon Hooper the check was complete. Liverpoolâ€™s complaints promoted the publication of the audio between officials which revealed the first person to spot the mistake was the replay operator, who urged the team of officials to stop the game, but the VAR and assistant VAR repeatedly said they could not intervene because play had restarted. Klopp felt such an unprecedented scenario required a similarly unprecedented solution. â€œThe audio didnâ€™t change it at all because I was not really interested in why things happened because I knew,â€ he said. â€œI saw the outcome, I saw goal we scored and it didnâ€™t count so I wasnâ€™t now waiting for the audio and sitting there hoping Iâ€™d find out how it could happen or whatever. â€œYes, it was an obvious mistake and I think there would have been solutions for it afterwards. â€œIf not, I can say immediately â€“ and probably some people donâ€™t want me to say it â€“ not as the manager of Liverpool but, much more as a football person, I think the only outcome should be a replay. It probably will not happen. â€œThe argument against that will probably be if you open that gate then everybody will ask for it. I think the situation is that unprecedented â€“ it didnâ€™t happen before. â€œIâ€™m 56 years old and Iâ€™m absolutely used to wrong decisions, difficult decisions but something like that as far as I can remember has never happened. Thatâ€™s why I think the replay would be the right thing. â€œThe next argument would be if it would happen again, I think a replay would be the right thing to do or the referee has the opportunity to bring both coaches together and say â€˜sorry, we made a mistake, but we can sort it, that Liverpool score a goal and we start from thereâ€™.â€ PGMOL can confirm that we have carried out a review into the circumstances which led to the Luis Diaz goal being incorrectly disallowed for offside in the Premier League match between Tottenham Hotspur FC and Liverpool FC. Full statement and the audio between the on-field teamâ€¦ â€” PGMOL (@FA_PGMOL) Asked whether the club had made â€“ or would make â€“ a formal request for the match to be replayed Klopp, after taking advice from his press officer, said: â€œWe are still going through the information that we have.â€ The PA news agency understands the Premier Leagueâ€™s stance remains the same as earlier in the week â€“ that a replay would not be considered. The manager stressed he did not want to single out the individuals involved for the errors made, but wanted to find a solution within the framework of the system which would prevent something similar recurring in futrure. â€œWhat I want to say is itâ€™s really important that as big as football is, and important as it is for us, that we really deal with it in a proper way,â€ he added. â€œI mean that all the people involved â€“ on-field ref, linesman, fourth official and especially now in this case VAR â€“ they didnâ€™t do that on purpose. We shouldnâ€™t forget that. â€œIâ€™m not angry with any of them (the officials), not at all. Itâ€™s not only the respect, but the only thing for human beings in general is we should not go for them. Itâ€™s not allowed to go for them in any way. â€œThey made a mistake and they felt horrible that night, Iâ€™m 100 per cent sure. Thatâ€™s enough for me. Nobody needs further punishment. We should discuss it on a completely normal basis without emotions.â€ Klopp was still unhappy with some other decisions taken in the game, notably the upgrading of Curtis Jonesâ€™ yellow card to a red, and also the two yellow cards issued to Diogo Jota. â€œThe referee got called to the screen and saw for the first three seconds a frozen picture. I would have given immediately a red card for that picture. Then he sees the replay in slow motion and Iâ€™d have given a red card for the slow motion. But in reality itâ€™s not a red card. â€œThe refâ€™s first decision is yellow. Then the clear and obvious mistake is showing a frozen picture and in slow motion. â€œOn top of that, Diogo Jota got two yellow cards for not touching a player once. That is unprecedented as well I would say.â€ Jota will be available for Thursdayâ€™s Europa League visit of Belgian side Union Saint Gilloise but fellow forward Cody Gakpo, who was injured in the Spurs game, is out. At our arrival at Anfield ahead of tonight's training session, we paid tribute to the 97 victims of the Hillsborough disaster. â€” Royale Union Saint-Gilloise (@UnionStGilloise) Union coach Alexander Blessin believes he could have been a Klopp player himself for Mainz. â€œHe was planning his new squad. He called me and asked â€˜How are you?â€™ â€˜Fineâ€™, â€˜Blah blah blahâ€™ and we knew each other there a little bit,â€ said the German. â€œHe said weâ€™d stay in contact and I never heard anything back.â€ On his sideâ€™s chances he added: â€œWe need a really perfect day and they need a bad day. â€œWe will do everything and arenâ€™t here just drinking coffee saying â€˜Oh, itâ€™s niceâ€™.â€
